importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Paris Climate Agreement was signed in 2015, marking a pivotal moment in global climate policy. Its implementation has significantly altered projected warming trajectories, reducing expected superhot days from 114 to 57 annually.
The study's baseline period (1991–2020) is used to define normal temperature comparisons, establishing a reference point for measuring climate change impacts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study projects future increases in superhot days through 2100, with current emissions trends leading to an additional 57 such days annually by the end of the century.

keyTakeAways: Climate change is increasing the number of dangerous 'superhot days'—defined as warmer than 90% of historical days between 1991 and 2020—by 57 per year under current emission pathways.
The Paris Climate Agreement has reduced projected warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, cutting the number of superhot days from 114 to 57 annually, though the future remains dangerous.
Since 2015, the world has already added 11 average superhot days per year due to climate change.

The impact of climate change is highly unequal: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face the largest increases in superhot days, despite contributing negligibly to global emissions.
Major emitters such as the United States, China, and India face only 23–30 additional superhot days, despite accounting for 42% of global CO2 emissions.
Experts warn that this disparity may deepen global inequities and fuel geopolitical instability, as vulnerable nations suffer disproportionate climate impacts.

The study, conducted by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central, uses established climate attribution methods and is not yet peer-reviewed, but its findings are based on robust modeling techniques.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agreement is central to the study's analysis, as it shifted global warming projections from 4°C to 2.6°C, directly affecting the number of superhot days.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new climate study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that climate change will add 57 superhot days annually by 2100 under current emissions pathways—half the increase from the pre-Paris 4°C warming scenario. While the Paris Agreement has reduced warming projections from 4°C to 2.6°C, the impacts remain severe, with vulnerable small island nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa facing massive spikes in dangerous heat days (up to 149 extra days per year), despite contributing negligibly to global emissions. In contrast, major polluters like the U.S., China, and India face only 23–30 additional superhot days. Experts warn that this stark disparity exacerbates global inequities and may contribute to future geopolitical tensions, emphasizing that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected annually by rising extreme heat.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
